docs.lead_paragraph: During a trans-Atlantic flight, I heard an announcement: ''If any doctors are on board, please make themselves known.'' At this point, I had worked in the hospital for only 18 months, but no one else came forward, so I treated a crew member with chest pain. As the crew thanked me, one pointed out that there were other doctors on the plane. Did I have an ethical obligation to care for a person at 30,000 feet? Kenneth Christopher, M.D., Brookline, Mass. You did the right thing. While U.S. law does not compel you to render aid in an emergency, the American Medical Association imposes an ethical obligation to do so, a policy that is both reasonable and humane.

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 6-29-03: THE ETHICIST

docs.abstract: Randy Cohen The Ethicist column answers questions about whether doctor has ethical obligation to care for fellow passenger during trans-Atlantic flight; on whether person is obligated to pay friend for dinner he could not attend at dinner club (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BEFORE I went to Brazil in March, I called my health insurance provider to find out about my coverage when traveling abroad. A representative told me I would be covered in case of an emergency, but was quick to point out that if I was planning a South American tummy tuck or any other nonemergency procedure -- apparently not an uncommon reason for a trip to a country known for its runway models -- then I was on my own.
docs.abstract: Susan Stellin Practical Traveler column offers advice on medical emergencies; notes many health insurance companies do not cover injuries or illnesses, including emergency care, while traveling abroad; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''The Rising Price of Getting Well'' (June 22) failed, as do many other articles about health-care issues, to distinguish between ''cost'' and ''price.'' The cost of health care is related to its fundamental value as determined by the immutable forces of an aging population in an advanced technocratic society. Over time, the cost of care must increase.

headline.main: A Solution To Health Care Crisis

docs.abstract: Dr Lawrence A Danto letter on June 22 article holds that while cost of health care is determined by aging population, price is determined by economy and market conditions

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the last couple of summers, the Fourth of July has been especially enjoyable and relaxing for the Franci family of West Haven. That is because Pete Franci no longer has to smuggle contraband home to celebrate. To the Francis, Independence Day means fireworks, and during the last 10 years, Mr. Franci sometimes bought illegal items like M-80 firecrackers and cherry bombs from what he called a ''connection'' within the state.
docs.abstract: Article on changes wrought by 2000 law in Connecticut legalizing sale of ground-based sparklers; American Pyrotechnics Assn reports fireworks injuries have dropped 75 percent nationwide since 1990; photos (M)
